speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: But, did they always have the same tune to it?

speaker: Harold B. Hazelhurst
words: Oh yes, they had the same tune all the time but different wording, you know. They would make up words all the time. You see, the fellows from different railroads would come and work on this track with us and each fellow, perhaps he'd have a new verse that he'd add to the song.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Well, good. Well now, let's hear it the way that you remember it.

speaker: Harold B. Hazelhurst
words: Well, sing it over again? Sing it now?

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Start from the beginning. Alright.

speaker: Distortion
words: [Distortion]

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Tell us about this.

speaker: Harold B. Hazelhurst
words: Every morning about four o'clock, the foreman, the tent, sack rouster, would go around and knock on the tent with his axe handle. Says 'Alright boys, let's go back'. Says 'Let's go back boys to double track. The work ain't hard, the man ain't mean. The cook ain't nasty, but the grub ain't clean. You sleep on my good bed and you call 'em bunk. You eat my good ration, and you call it junk. So, now let's go back.'

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: How was the arrangement, how was the arrangement of the tents?

speaker: Harold B. Hazelhurst
words: The tents were in circles. And each, they were built in circles so as when he'd leave the last tent, he would be at the first tent again. He'd go all around and when he stopped at the last tent, he'd be right back at the first tent again.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Well, he was the foreman of the job?

speaker: Harold B. Hazelhurst
words: Well, he was one of the foremans on the job.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Uh-huh.

speaker: Harold B. Hazelhurst
words: So, they would take turns in arousing the men every morning but this particular man, he would use those phrase.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Uh-huh. And he just said them like that?

speaker: Harold B. Hazelhurst
words: Yes, he didn't have no expression whatever. [Laughter]. It was just dry.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: [Laughter]. Even if he had no expression, let's hear it again.

speaker: Harold B. Hazelhurst
words: Come on boys, let's go back to double track. The work ain't hard, and the man ain't mean. The cook ain't nasty, but the grub ain't clean. You sleep on the good beds and you call 'em bunk. You eat my good rations, and you call it junk. So, now let's go back.'

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Tell me when it would be different.

speaker: Harold B. Hazelhurst
words: Well, sometime, when the boss man wouldn't go around himself, he'd send some of the fellas, colored fellas, around to arouse the men. They'd say 'Come on boys, let's go back. Yes, you sleep on his good beds and you call 'em bunk,  You eat his good rations, and you call 'em junk. So, now if I have to call it, you want to fight. Now that white man call it, it's captain alright. Now, let's go back.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Alright. Tell us about it.

speaker: Harold B. Hazelhurst
words: All of these songs that I'm singing, they didn't have no particular title. We just began singing them as the feelings would come on.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Alright, when did the feelings come on for this one?

speaker: Harold B. Hazelhurst
words: Well, sometimes the fellas, it'd be near pay day, and some of the fellas would think about going away to another job and they began feeling good. They began singing some of these songs and this one, in particular.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Go ahead.

speaker: Distortion
words: [Distortion]

speaker: H. W. Stuckey
words: During the early days of the settlers in South Carolina, Buford County, when the church was first established there, before there were schools and seminaries, why the preachers preached mostly by imagination, and as I've been in contact during my boyhood days with quite a few settlers from that part of the state, I've learned this sermon how an old minister use to preach it a long time ago and instead of being able to reiterate from the bible, he just imagined something and went on to preach it in a form of dialect as I shall give you now as near as I can imitate him.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: What was that song? When did that song come in?

speaker: H. W. Stuckey
words: [Laughter] On the close of the sermon, they open the doors of the church after he got through.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Yeah and who would sing it?

speaker: H. W. Stuckey
words: Old sister in the corner.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Well I mean was there any particular reason for singing this song? Was that at the opening of the church door?

speaker: H. W. Stuckey
words: At the opening of the church door according to the members, the church members.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: And this was the song that was used, she would use?

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Would you sing it over again, please?

speaker: Zora Neale Hurston
words: Uh Zora Hurston speaking. In all the big work camps, sawmills, and turpentine, still, and road camps and whatnot they have a man to go down and wake up the camp. And he has various chants and hollers to wake them up and sometimes he wakes them up as he goes along.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Well, speaking about what you're getting ready to, Where'd you hear that?

speaker: Zora Neale Hurston
words: Well, I heard these at Loughman, a big sawmill down state in Polk County.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Alright

speaker: Carita Doggett Corse
words: What kind of a song is this, Zora?

speaker: Zora Neale Hurston
words: This is a Nassau song from the Bahamas.

speaker: Carita Doggett Corse
words: When is it used?

speaker: Zora Neale Hurston
words: Well, they sing this song when they're jumping the fire dance.

speaker: Carita Doggett Corse
words: What is the fire dance?

speaker: Zora Neale Hurston
words: The fire dance is some sort of African survival in the West Indies and they beat the drums and sing these little songs.

speaker: Carita Doggett Corse
words: And how did you happen to learn it?

speaker: Zora Neale Hurston
words: Well, I was doing research down there, collecting songs out of Columbia University and I collected quite a few of them and this is just one of them.

speaker: Zora Neale Hurston
words: And they keep that up until the drum is cold and then they change it and they sing another song of the same kind.

speaker: Carita Doggett Corse
words: What is this?

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: You better sing another song of the same kind.

speaker: Zora Neale Hurston
words: Uh, this one, this song is [distortion].

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Wait [distortion]

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Go ahead. Next song.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: This little song is a story. Uh, the young lady thinks that it's time for them to get married. in fact, she thinks they just have to and the boy doesn't want to marry and so this song is about it.

speaker: Carita Doggett Corse
words: Are those songs sung in Florida as well as in the West Indies?

speaker: Zora Neale Hurston
words: Yes, Dr. Corse. Uh, they are sung in Key West and Miami and Palm Beach and out in the Everglades where a great number of Nassaus are working in the bean fields and whatnot. Uh, there are a great number of them in Florida who hold jumping dances every week.

speaker: Carita Doggett Corse
words: I think it's very interesting that we have inferences from the West Indies as well as the rural South in our Florida Negro folklore.

speaker: Gilberto
words: Gilberto

speaker: Art Pages
words: What Mr. Gilberto [inaudible] just said is that he is manager of a Latin group now playing at the Cuban Club in Tampa Florida who are going to sing for you some of their traditional Cuban songs.  I am the pianist of the unit, Art Pages, and will play some of them for you myself.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Uh, Mr. Pages, Will you tell me where are the people from?

speaker: Art Pages
words: Uh, all these units, all of the actors in the unit are all native Cubans and they came from Cuba two or three months ago.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Uh, will you, can you, tell me in their performance do they play some of the old songs? The traditional songs?

speaker: Art Pages
words: They have to for they are requested to do so.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Good. Go ahead.

speaker: Art Pages
words: Uh, the melody that Estella [inaudible] will sing for you next is a typical Cuban melody. This is sung in the country by the peasants. It's probably uh . . . I don't know what to say.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Well, stay there. How long has she known this song?

speaker: Art Pages
words: Oh, that, she's probably heard it all her life from her parents and so forth.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Well, you go up there and ask her. You ask her.

speaker: Art Pages
words: Do you want me to do that in Spanish?

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Go ahead and ask her.

speaker: Art Pages
words: In Spanish?

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Sure. Go ahead.

speaker: Art Pages
words: AP asks question in Spanish and Estella responds.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Explain that to us what she said.

speaker: Art Pages
words: Uh, she has said that she has, uh, heard that melody, of course, recently due to the fact that she is very young but she has heard her parents say that have heard it for years and years back.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Ok, ask her to stay up, go up there and [inaudible] on the piano

speaker: Art Pages
words: Estella [inaudible] will sing this melody for you now.

speaker: Art Pages
words: Uh, the Cuban persons use songs to call on their loved ones especially at night or in the morning. The song that Estella [inaudible] sang is one of them. Uh, roughly, it is morning and he is singing to his loved one and though he claims that the sun is just out and he can see everything clearly, it seems like there is nothing around until he's seen her [distortion].

speaker: Unknown
words: Man speaks in Spanish

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: [inaudible] Explain what that song tells us [inaudible]

speaker: Art Pages
words: The young man that you have just heard sing is Carlos Poz. He is the blackfaced comedian of the unit, of the Cuban unit. He just sung for you a typical African song, songs that were sung by the slaves when they were brought to Cuba and he has picked that from tradition. That is, he has heard that type of song over and over.  It is always heard in Cuba.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: How is it, how is it accompanied when it is heard in Cuba?

speaker: Art Pages
words: Uh, they usually use Cuban drums and gourds and sticks like they used to use in the days of the slaves when they didn't have any musical instruments and they were accompanied by sticks and drums and so on.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: And that song is part of the regular [inaudible] around cane?

speaker: Art Pages
words: It is. We use it here, we use that type of songs here often.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Is it sung in Cuba by the whites or by the negroes?

speaker: Art Pages
words: Well, no, they, uh, it has been picked from the negroes but it is used by actors.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: What's that?

speaker: Carita Doggett Corse
words: [Inaudible]

speaker: Art Pages
words: Oh, they love it. It's such a strange rhythm to most of all people that they prefer to hear that song to any other.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Thank you, Mr. Pages [distortion].

speaker: Art Pages
words: Uh, the song that you have just heard Carlos Poz sing, it's sort of a negro song. It is a negro telling his girl not to mix with another, uh, tribe, because he does not consider them as good as they are and does not want to, uh,  mix the tribes. And --

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: What do you mean by mix the tribes?

speaker: Art Pages
words: Well, he does that, it seems like the, uh, girl is in love with someone and she, uh, goes to a nearby tribe and he does not want her to continue to go over there and he is asking her to please stay in her, in their grounds.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: He doesn't want to have children from the other tribe.

speaker: Art Pages
words: That's right [laughter] [distortion].

speaker: Art Pages
words: The song you have just heard was sung by [inaudible] Martinez. The name of the song is 'Merce'. It is a different type of song that have been sung before, for this one is dance, in dance halls in Cuba, that is that rhythm. You have also heard some Cuban drums played by Roman [inaudible] and Mr. Delfino was playing gourds and I was at the piano, Art Pages.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: [inaudible]

speaker: Art Pages
words: Carlos Poz helped her out by helping her sing in the montonu, that is the fast part of the number. The number is divided into two parts. The first part is sung a little slower than the second part. The second part is a little faster. They keep on getting faster until, uh, it takes up to a very fast tempo.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Now would you explain, translate what the words of the song are, what the words of the song are about? Roughly.

speaker: Carita Doggett Corse
words: What is it about? What is it about?

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Roughly, just offhand what does it say?

speaker: Carita Doggett Corse
words: What is it about? What is it about?

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: If you give me a chance. Would you cut it out? [Distortion]

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Alright.

speaker: Art Pages
words: The idea of the song is uh, the name of the song is 'Merce' and that's a, uh, name, a proper name. It's a negro girl's name and she is supposed to be the most popular of the party and the song refers to her popularity, that is her way of dancing and acting and speaking and so forth and everybody sings to her beauty and her pep, would you say? And the whole song is based on  her.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: [Inaudible]

speaker: Carita Doggett Corse
words: And did you get this one in [audible]. Did you say that?

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Can you stand up there and explain, give me names [inaudible]? The manager. Can you give his name?

speaker: Art Pages
words: Uh, the song that you heard was sung by Gilberto Elfino, manager of the unit. And the name of the song is 'Nena'.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Now, can you tell m, what type of song is it?

speaker: Art Pages
words: Uh, this is probably the oldest type of Cuban song that has ever, uh, that has been known to be the oldest.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: And, uh, where is it learned and how is such a song learned?

speaker: Art Pages
words: Uh, there is no way of tracing it to its author or its originality. It has just been picked from one generation to the other.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Now, can you tell what it's about that song? What does it say?

speaker: Art Pages
words: Well, I don't know [distortion].

speaker: Unknown
words: Man speaks in Spanish.

speaker: Art Pages
words: Uh, this is a typical song that is sung to a girl by a window, a Spanish, uh, window. And that's about all I know about the song.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Well, did you get the words from them?

speaker: Art Pages
words: No, I couldn't.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Ask them what the words are and you translate.

speaker: Unknown
words: Men speak Spanish

speaker: Art Pages
words: He just sing to her and telling her how much he loves her, and uh, i other words, uh, calling her to the window in order to start a conversation or something, a song to start a conversation [distortion].

speaker: Art Pages
words: We are now going to give you an idea of the different Cuban rhythms. The first one is a song, that's a slow rumba.

speaker: Art Pages
words: Now, he would play a rumba. That's a faster rhythm.

speaker: Art Pages
words: And now a bembe. That's a typical African rhythm.

speaker: Art Pages
words: And now, a conga.

speaker: Art Pages
words: And now, man. This is probably the oldest rhythm going.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Just tell him, tell him --

speaker: Art Pages
words: This was done by Ramon [inaudible] a Cuban drummer.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: And Art Pages, a pianist, was giving the announcement.

speaker: Distortion
words: [Distortion]

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: [inaudible]

speaker: Roberts
words: Roberts (R): A very long time ago I learned about a funny song, that's all I know. If you like funny songs.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Where did you learn that song?

speaker: Roberts
words: I learned it all in the [inaudible].

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Go ahead and sing it to me.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: [inaudible] the last lines of that song, Mr. Roberts. Repeat it for me.

speaker: Roberts
words: The last lines?

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: You said there's something in my . . . there's something in my hammond.

speaker: Roberts
words: yes [inaudible].

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: What did you mean by that last line?

speaker: Roberts
words: I meant that uh, to clear my throat. There's something in my hammond, see? And then I said [clears throat], There's something in my hammond, See? That's the end of the song when I said there's something in my hammond.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: What song are you going to sing next, Mr. Roberts?

speaker: Roberts
words: Sweet Robin One Morning in May' [inaudible]

speaker: Roberts
words: [Inaudible] down the well and he'd sit there down in the well and they'd call his name so when after he got a song up [inaudible] and he said it so much, he said, 'Is that your name, Betty?' Oh, he said, 'that's my name Betty.'

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Will you tell us the riddle that you're talking about, Mr. Roberts?

speaker: Roberts
words: Oh, about the men?

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: That's right.

speaker: Roberts
words: How a fellow knows about his name [Distortion] He'd look in the well and then see his picture in the well and he'd say [inaudible] He said these words [inaudible] 'Is that your name, Betty?' Oh, he said, 'that's my name Betty.' That was the first time he ever told anybody's name.

speaker: Inaudible
words: [Inaudible]

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: [Inaudible]

speaker: Roberts
words: What do you want me to sing now?

speaker: Inaudible
words: [Inaudible]

speaker: Inaudible
words: [Inaudible]

speaker: Roberts
words: Feel like I could give you a sample [inaudible]. I'm going to sing it now, eh?

speaker: Inaudible
words: [Inaudible]

speaker: Inaudible
words: [Inaudible]

speaker: Roberts
words: Well, I want to tell you just about how good tobacco is.

speaker: Roberts
words: . . . up there, up there from where the hurricanes always start from, what's it called, Puerto Rico.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: He was the one who told you that story?

speaker: Roberts
words: Yes.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Was he a Puerto Rican?

speaker: Roberts
words: Yes.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: How'd he come to tell it to you?

speaker: Roberts
words: I don't know [laughter]. Just setting down talking to him one day.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Where were you then?

speaker: Roberts
words: I was here in Florida and he was in Florida too [inaudible]

speaker: Inaudible
words: [Inaudible]

speaker: Inaudible
words: [Inaudible]

words: [Inaudible]

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: What part of the Bahamas Where were you born, Mr. Roberts? What part of the Bahamas? How far from Nassau?

speaker: Roberts
words: I was born in the Abacos.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Oh, Abacos.

speaker: Roberts
words: [Inaudible] part of Abacos, yes.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: How far from Nassau?

speaker: Roberts
words: About a hundred miles from Nassau [inaudible]

words: go ahead and tell us this riddle, then.
